elements.content: Eleven Zn/Cd-containing coordination polymers (CPs) incorporating both flexible 4-substituted bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands and polycarboxylate anions, namely, [Zn(L1)(o-BDC)]·1.5H2O (1), [Zn(L1)(m-BDC)] (2), [Cd2(L1)(BTEC)]·H2O (3), [Zn(L2)(m-BDC)]·1.25H2O (4), [Zn(L2)(p-BDC)]·4H2O (5), [Cd(L2)(p-BDC)]·H2O (6), [Zn2(L2)(BTEC)] (7), [Zn(L3)(m-BDC)]·3.5H2O (8), [Zn2(L3)(p-BDC)2]·2H2O (9), [Zn2(L3)2(BTEC)]·2H2O (10), and [Cd2(L3)2(BTEC)] (11) {L1 = 1,2-bis[2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane, L2 = 1,2-bis[3-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane, L3 = 1,2-bis[4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane, o-H2BDC = phthalic acid, m-H2BDC = isophthalic acid, p-H2BDC = terephthalic acid, and H4BTEC = pyromellitic acid} have been prepared and identified by physical measurements. Compound 1 possesses a layered structure. Compound 2 shows one-dimensional chains. Weak π–π intermolecular stackings further join these chains into a two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular layered structure. Compound 3 displays a three-dimensional (3D) (4,8)-connected (32·42·52)(34·48·512·64) net. Compound 4 consists of two interlocked single-wall metal–organic nanotubes (SWMONTs) with both polyrotaxane and polycatenane characters. Compound 5 exhibits a 3D 5-fold interpenetrating diamond motif. Compound 6 furnishes a 3D α-Po net. Compound 7 reveals a 3D (4,6)-connected net with (43·63)(46·66·83) topology. Compound 8 features a 2D 4-connected network with (65·8) topology. Compound 9 shows a 3D 3-fold interpenetrating α-Po net. Compounds 10 and 11 display 3D (4,4)-connected nets with the same (64·7·8)(62·84) topology. The effects of the bis(triazole) ligands, aromatic polycarboxylate anions, and metals ions on the framework assemblies have been discussed. Solid-state luminescent of compounds 1–11 are reported as well. Moreover, fluorescent properties of compounds 4–7 in various solvent suspensions were investigated at room temperature.

elements.content: A series of CPs constructed by flexible 4-substituted bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands and polycarboxylate anions were successfully synthesized and structurally characterized, where fluorescent properties of some compounds in various solvent emulsions were investigated at room temperature.

elements.content: Recently, research in the coordination polymers (CPs) has made great progress. Up to date, numerous CPs have been studied for their enormous varieties of interesting structural topologies, as well as their promising application as functionalized materials. A great deal of mixed-ligand CPs involved in flexible N-donor bridging ligands, such as bis(pyridine), bis(imidazole), bis(tetrazole) ligands, have been reported. These ligands could bend or rotate freely and feature various coordination conformations during the assembly with metal centers, which usually result in structural diversities. Currently, flexible bis(triazole) ligands have received great interest because of their good coordination abilities to metal ions and promising versatile coordination chemistry. In the previous work, bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands containing flexible alkyl or aryl spacers in the N1 position of triazole rings have been certified to be excellent ligands for designing CPs. For example, 1,n-bis(triazole-1-yl)alkane (n = 2–6 and 10), 1,4-bis[(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)methyl]benzene, and 4,4′-bis(1,2,4-triazole-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl have been utilized in the assembly of CPs. By contrast, the study on flexible bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands with spacers in the N4 position of 1,2,4-triazole rings is relatively rare. The flexible 4-substituted bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands can link metal centers through one and/or two nitrogen donors from each triazole group, leading to μ2-N1:N1′ (bidentate), μ3-N1:N2:N1′ (tridentate), and μ4-N1:N2:N1′:N2′ (tetradentate) coordination modes. To get further investigation about the effects of the flexible bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands on the architectures of CPs, we synthesized three new structurally related ligands, namely, 1,2-bis[2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane (L1), 1,2-bis[3-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane (L2), and 1,2-bis[4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane (L3). These ligands possess the same flexible −[phenyl–O–(CH2)2–O–phenyl]– spacer in the N4 position of 1,2,4-triazole rings and can bend and rotate freely in the assembly process. Usually, the construction of CPs can be affected by organic anions. The polycarboxylate anions acting as excellent organic connectors are fundamental roles in directing the overall structure of CPs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, research in the coordination polymers (CPs) has made great progress. Up to date, numerous CPs have been studied for their enormous varieties of interesting structural topologies, as well as their promising application as functionalized materials. A great deal of mixed-ligand CPs involved in flexible N-donor bridging ligands, such as bis(pyridine), bis(imidazole), bis(tetrazole) ligands, have been reported. These ligands could bend or rotate freely and feature various coordination conformations during the assembly with metal centers, which usually result in structural diversities. Currently, flexible bis(triazole) ligands have received great interest because of their good coordination abilities to metal ions and promising versatile coordination chemistry. In the previous work, bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands containing flexible alkyl or aryl spacers in the N1 position of triazole rings have been certified to be excellent ligands for designing CPs. For example, 1,n-bis(triazole-1-yl)alkane (n = 2-6 and 10), 1,4-bis[(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)methyl]benzene, and 4,4'-bis(1,2,4-triazole-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl have been utilized in the assembly of CPs. By contrast, the study on flexible bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands with spacers in the N4 position of 1,2,4-triazole rings is relatively rare. The flexible 4-substituted bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands can link metal centers through one and/or two nitrogen donors from each triazole group, leading to μ2-N1:N1' (bidentate), μ3-N1:N2:N1' (tridentate), and μ4-N1:N2:N1':N2' (tetradentate) coordination modes. To get further investigation about the effects of the flexible bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands on the architectures of CPs, we synthesized three new structurally related ligands, namely, 1,2-bis[2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane (L1), 1,2-bis[3-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane (L2), and 1,2-bis[4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane (L3). These ligands possess the same flexible -[phenyl-O-(CH2)2-O-phenyl]- spacer in the N4 position of 1,2,4-triazole rings and can bend and rotate freely in the assembly process. Usually, the construction of CPs can be affected by organic anions. The polycarboxylate anions acting as excellent organic connectors are fundamental roles in directing the overall structure of CPs.

elements.content: With considerations mentioned above, eleven CPs constructed by L1–L3 ligands and polycarboxylate anions (Scheme ), namely, [Zn(L1)(o-BDC)]·1.5H2O (1), [Zn(L1)(m-BDC)] (2), [Cd2(L1)(BTEC)]·H2O (3), [Zn(L2)(m-BDC)]·1.25H2O (4), [Zn(L2)(p-BDC)]·4H2O (5), [Cd(L2)(p-BDC)]·H2O (6), [Zn2(L2)(BTEC)] (7), [Zn(L3)(m-BDC)]·3.5H2O (8), [Zn2(L3)(p-BDC)2]·2H2O (9), [Zn2(L3)2(BTEC)]·2H2O (10), and [Cd2(L3)2(BTEC)] (11) {L1 = 1,2-bis[2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane, L2 = 1,2-bis[3-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane, L3 = 1,2-bis[4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenoxy]ethane, o-H2BDC = phthalic acid, m-H2BDC = isophthalic acid, p-H2BDC = terephthalic acid, and H4BTEC = pyromellitic acid) have been prepared and identified by physical measurements. The results illustrate that the structural diversities of compounds are strongly dependent on ligands and metal ions. Moreover, the fluorescent properties of compounds 4–7 in various solvent suspensions were investigated at room temperature.

elements.content: The 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol, 3-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol, and 4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol were prepared by published procedures. All other chemicals for syntheses were commercially available.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol, 3-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol, and 4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol were prepared by published procedures. All other chemicals for syntheses were commercially available.

elements.content:
Microanalysis of C, H, and N, FT-IR spectra, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data, and fluorescent spectra were conducted using published methods.

Syntheses of <bold>L1</bold>–<bold>L3</bold>

A mixture of 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol (30 mmol) and NaOH (30 mmol) in EtOH (100 mL) was refluxed with stirring for 1 h, and then 1,2-dibromoethane (15 mmol) was added. After refluxing for 10 h, ethanol was removed and 100 mL water was added. Colorless crystalline solid (2.8 g) of L1 was obtained overnight. Yield: 2.8 g (54%). The preparations of L2 and L3 were similar to that of L1 except that 3-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol and 4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol were used instead of 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol, respectively. Yields: 3.5 g (67%) for L2 and 3.1 g (59%) for L3.
elements.clean_text:

After refluxing for 10 h, ethanol was removed and 100 mL water was added. Colorless crystalline solid (2.8 g) of L1 was obtained overnight. Yield: 2.8 g (54%). Yields: 3.5 g (67%) for L2 and 3.1 g (59%) for L3.

elements.content: The techniques used for single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collection and absorption corrections were the same as that in reported literature. Structure solution and refinement were performed by using SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs implemented in WINGX. The non-H atoms of compounds 1–11 were recognized in electron-density maps and refined anisotropically. For 8, the split-atom model was applied to disordered atoms (O7, O7′, O8, O8′, C44, and C44′). The CH and OH hydrogen atoms were fixed in idealized positions and found from difference Fourier maps, respectively. All H atoms are refined as riding on their respective atoms. Some OH atoms on lattice water molecules in compounds 1, 3, 4, 6, and 8–10 could not have been found from the residual peaks. Crystallographic details for 1–11 are summarized in Table , as well as Tables S1–S11 (). Network topologies were calculated by using OLEX.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determinations

The techniques used for single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collection and absorption corrections were the same as that in reported literature. Structure solution and refinement were performed by using SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs implemented in WINGX. The non-H atoms of compounds 1-11 were recognized in electron-density maps and refined anisotropically. For 8, the split-atom model was applied to disordered atoms (O7, O7', O8, O8', C44, and C44'). The CH and OH hydrogen atoms were fixed in idealized positions and found from difference Fourier maps, respectively. All H atoms are refined as riding on their respective atoms. Some OH atoms on lattice water molecules in compounds 1, 3, 4, 6, and 8-10 could not have been found from the residual peaks. Crystallographic details for 1-11 are summarized in Table , as well as Tables S1-S11 (). Network topologies were calculated by using OLEX.

elements.content: In 1, each Zn(II) ion possesses a tetrahedron configuration, which is completed by two L1 ligands as N donors and two o-BDC anions as O-donors (Figure a). The L1 as a bidentate ligand displays a TGT conformation (T = trans, G = gauche, Scheme S1a of the ). In this fashion, L1 ligands hold Zn(II) ions together, leading to the production of a wavelike chain with the Zn···Zn distance across the L1 ligand of 12.2228(6) Å (Figure b). The neighboring chains are then joined by the o-BDC anions with carboxylate groups in μ1-η1:η0 modes (Scheme S2a of the ), forming a 2D-layered structure (Figure c).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure of [Zn(L1)(o-BDC)]⋅1.5H2O (1)

In 1, each Zn(II) ion possesses a tetrahedron configuration, which is completed by two L1 ligands as N donors and two o-BDC anions as O-donors (Figure a). The L1 as a bidentate ligand displays a TGT conformation (T = trans, G = gauche, Scheme S1a of the ). In this fashion, L1 ligands hold Zn(II) ions together, leading to the production of a wavelike chain with the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance across the L1 ligand of 12.2228(6) Å (Figure b). The neighboring chains are then joined by the o-BDC anions with carboxylate groups in μ1-η1:η0 modes (Scheme S2a of the ), forming a 2D-layered structure (Figure c).

elements.content: In 2, each Zn(II) ion is surrounded by a couple of L1 ligands as N-donors, and two m-BDC anions as O-donors, exhibiting a [N2O2] tetrahedral sphere (Figure a). Different from 1, L1 ligand in 2 takes a TGT′ conformation (Scheme S1b of the ). In this way, two L1 ligands bridge double Zn(II) ions to yield a macrocyclic [Zn2(L1)2] loop with Zn···Zn distance of 6.1941(4) Å. Neighboring loops are then linked by the m-BDC anions with carboxylate groups in μ1-η1:η0 (Scheme S2b of the ) modes, affording a 1D chain (Figure b). Moreover, these 1D chains interact with each other through π–π intermolecular stackings (with interplane spacing and centroid–centroid distance between phenyl rings of 3.66 Å and of 3.68 Å, respectively), forming an extended 2D layerlike structure (Figure S1 of the ).

elements.content: In 3, both two Cd(II) ions lie in hexa-coordinated spheres, and each one is surrounded by one L1 ligand as a N-donor and three BTEC anions as O-donors, leading to the formation of distorted octahedral coordination geometry (Figure a). In each BTEC anion, two meta-positioned carboxylate groups exhibit the same bidentate bridging (μ2-η1:η1) coordination mode, whereas the remaining two exhibit a μ2-η2:η1 coordination mode (Scheme S2g of the ). These two kinds of BTEC anions link two types of Cd(II) ions, giving a 2D sheet (Figure b). The L1 ligands which adopt GGG conformations (Scheme S1c of the ) bridge adjacent 2D layers to yield a 3D framework with Cd···Cd separations of 11.9160(6) Å (Figure S2 of the ).

Structure of [Cd2(L1)(BTEC)]⋅H2O (3)

In 3, both two Cd(II) ions lie in hexa-coordinated spheres, and each one is surrounded by one L1 ligand as a N-donor and three BTEC anions as O-donors, leading to the formation of distorted octahedral coordination geometry (Figure a). In each BTEC anion, two meta-positioned carboxylate groups exhibit the same bidentate bridging (μ2-η1:η1) coordination mode, whereas the remaining two exhibit a μ2-η2:η1 coordination mode (Scheme S2g of the ). These two kinds of BTEC anions link two types of Cd(II) ions, giving a 2D sheet (Figure b). The L1 ligands which adopt GGG conformations (Scheme S1c of the ) bridge adjacent 2D layers to yield a 3D framework with Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separations of 11.9160(6) Å (Figure S2 of the ).

elements.content: Topologically, by considering the BTEC anion as one 4-connecting node and two adjacent Cd(II) ions as one 8-connecting node, compound 3 can be rationalized as a 3D (4, 8)-connected framework evaluated as (32·42·52)(34·48·512·64) topology (Figure c).

elements.content: In 4, both two Zn(II) ions are in tetrahedral coordination spheres, and each one is surrounded by two L2 ligands as N-donors and two m-BDC anions as O-donors (Figure a). For convenience, the L2 ligands containing N1 and N7 are designated L2′ and L2″, respectively. The m-BDC anions containing O5 and O9 are designated m-BDC′ and m-BDC″, respectively. On the one hand, two L2′ ligands bridge Zn1 and its symmetry-related species to form a 2-membered [Zn2(L2)2] metallocyclic ring. Adjacent [Zn2(L2)2] metallocyclic rings are linked by m-BDC′ anions in a double-bridged fashion to form an open-ended, hollow single-wall metal–organic nanotube (SWMONT) (Figure b) with the interior cross-section dimensions of ca. 10.24 × 10.46 Å. On the other hand, L2″ ligands and m-BDC″ anions link Zn2 ions to form anther SWMONT with the interior cross-section dimensions of ca. 9.80 × 10.81 Å. Interestingly, each SWMONT is interlocked in a parallel fashion with the other one to minimize the cavities and stabilize the network (Figure c). As far as we know, this kind of entanglement is quite uncommon. Additionally, in 4, two kinds of L2 ligands adopt GTT and TTT conformations (Scheme S1, panels d and e, of the ) with Zn···Zn separations of 15.4982(6) and 15.8188(6) Å, respectively. The carboxylate groups of two kinds of m-BDC anions shows the same monodentate (μ1-η1:η0) (Scheme S2b of the ) coordination mode.

Structure of [Zn(L2)(m-BDC)]⋅1.25H2O (4)

In 4, both two Zn(II) ions are in tetrahedral coordination spheres, and each one is surrounded by two L2 ligands as N-donors and two m-BDC anions as O-donors (Figure a). For convenience, the L2 ligands containing N1 and N7 are designated L2' and L2", respectively. The m-BDC anions containing O5 and O9 are designated m-BDC' and m-BDC", respectively. On the one hand, two L2' ligands bridge Zn1 and its symmetry-related species to form a 2-membered [Zn2(L2)2] metallocyclic ring. Adjacent [Zn2(L2)2] metallocyclic rings are linked by m-BDC' anions in a double-bridged fashion to form an open-ended, hollow single-wall metal-organic nanotube (SWMONT) (Figure b) with the interior cross-section dimensions of ca. 10.24 × 10.46 Å. On the other hand, L2" ligands and m-BDC" anions link Zn2 ions to form anther SWMONT with the interior cross-section dimensions of ca. 9.80 × 10.81 Å. Interestingly, each SWMONT is interlocked in a parallel fashion with the other one to minimize the cavities and stabilize the network (Figure c). As far as we know, this kind of entanglement is quite uncommon. Additionally, in 4, two kinds of L2 ligands adopt GTT and TTT conformations (Scheme S1, panels d and e, of the ) with Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separations of 15.4982(6) and 15.8188(6) Å, respectively. The carboxylate groups of two kinds of m-BDC anions shows the same monodentate (μ1-η1:η0) (Scheme S2b of the ) coordination mode.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that the structure of 4 shows both polyrotaxane and polycatenane characters. The m-BDC anion acts as a rod and threads into the [Zn2(L2)2] loop from the other SWMONT. Two kinds of loops of the [Zn2(L2)2] and the [Zn4(L2)2(m-BDC)2] from adjacent SWMONT catenate each other (Figure d). For all we know, compound 4 represents the first case of 1D SWMONTs possessing both polyrotaxane and polycatenane characters.

elements.content: In 5, each Zn(II) ion locates in the core of tetrahedron sphere completed by two L2 ligands as N-donors and two p-BDC anions as O-donors (Figure a). As presented in Figure S3 of the , p-BDC anions bridge Zn(II) ions through carboxylate groups (μ1-η0:η1 mode, Scheme S2c of the ), taking on a 1D chain. Further linkage of these chains by L2 ligands in the same TTT′ conformation (Scheme S1f of the ) gives a 3D framework with Zn···Zn separations of 19.2307(1) and 23.1215(2) Å, respectively (Figure b).

elements.content: Topologically, by depicting Zn(II) ions as 4-connectors, compound 5 can be viewed as a typical diamond net with rather large voids (Figure c). Five independent infinite nets are then interpenetrated to furnish a 5-fold interpenetrating diamond motif (Figure d).

elements.content: In 6, each seven-coordinated Cd(II) ion is surrounded by a couple of L2 ligands as N-donors and three different p-BDC anions as O-donors, producing a [N2O5] pentagonal bipyramid configuration (Figure a). For convenience, the p-BDC anions containing O3 and O5 are designated p-BDC′ and p-BDC″, respectively. Two carboxylate groups of p-BDC′ anion take μ2-η1:η2 coordination modes (Scheme S2d of the ), whereas the ones of the p-BDC″ anion display chelate–bidentate (μ1-η1:η1) coordination modes (Scheme S2e of the ). The carboxylate groups of p-BDC′ anions held neighboring Cd(II) ions together to yield a dinuclear Cd(II) unit, which are extended by the backbones of two kinds of p-BDC anions into a layer (Figure b). Adjacent layers are linked by L2 ligands in TTT′ conformations (Scheme S1f of the ), into a 3D framework with Cd···Cd separation of 19.170(1) Å (Figure S4 of the ).
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [Cd(L2)(p-BDC)]⋅H2O (6)

In 6, each seven-coordinated Cd(II) ion is surrounded by a couple of L2 ligands as N-donors and three different p-BDC anions as O-donors, producing a [N2O5] pentagonal bipyramid configuration (Figure a). For convenience, the p-BDC anions containing O3 and O5 are designated p-BDC' and p-BDC", respectively. Two carboxylate groups of p-BDC' anion take μ2-η1:η2 coordination modes (Scheme S2d of the ), whereas the ones of the p-BDC" anion display chelate-bidentate (μ1-η1:η1) coordination modes (Scheme S2e of the ). The carboxylate groups of p-BDC' anions held neighboring Cd(II) ions together to yield a dinuclear Cd(II) unit, which are extended by the backbones of two kinds of p-BDC anions into a layer (Figure b). Adjacent layers are linked by L2 ligands in TTT' conformations (Scheme S1f of the ), into a 3D framework with Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separation of 19.170(1) Å (Figure S4 of the ).

elements.content: In this work, L1–L3 ligands display the same μ2-N1:N1′ coordination modes. However, these ligands can take various conformations due to the existence of a flexible −(phenyl–O–(CH2)2–O–phenyl)– spacer (Scheme S1 of the ). The σ bonds can rotate freely, and therefore the three neighboring bonds of the −O–(CH2)2–O– group can arrange in T or G orientations (T = trans and G = gauche). For example, in compounds 1–3, the L1 ligands display TGT, TGT′, and GGG conformations with M(II)···M(II) distances linked by L1 ligands from 6.1941(4) to 12.2228(6) Å. In the TGT and TGT′ conformations, the spacers of the two L1 ligands show the same conformation, but the arrangements of their triazole groups are slightly different (Scheme S1 of the ). The dihedral angles between two triazole groups from one L1 ligand in the TGT and TGT′ conformations are 49.53 and 72.85°, respectively. In compounds 4–7, the L2 ligands show GTT, TTT, and TTT′ conformations with M(II)···M(II) separations from 15.4982(6) to 23.1215(2) Å. In the TTT and TTT′ conformations, the spacers of two L2 ligands arrange in the same pattern. However, the two triazole groups of the L2 ligand in the two compounds show different directions (Scheme S1 of the ). The dihedral angles between two triazole groups from one L2 ligand in the TTT and TTT′ conformations are 27.06 and 0° (or 5.63°), respectively. In compounds 8–11, the L3 ligands exhibit TTT, TGT, and GTG conformations with M(II)···M(II) distances across them from 20.6576(9) to 27.2784(4) Å. The average M(II)···M(II) distances separated by relative L1–L3 ligands gradually increase with the changes of triazole group positions of bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conformations of Flexible Bis(1,2,4-triazole) Ligands

In this work, L1-L3 ligands display the same μ2-N1:N1' coordination modes. However, these ligands can take various conformations due to the existence of a flexible -(phenyl-O-(CH2)2-O-phenyl)- spacer (Scheme S1 of the ). The σ bonds can rotate freely, and therefore the three neighboring bonds of the -O-(CH2)2-O- group can arrange in T or G orientations (T = trans and G = gauche). For example, in compounds 1-3, the L1 ligands display TGT, TGT', and GGG conformations with M(II)⋅⋅⋅M(II) distances linked by L1 ligands from 6.1941(4) to 12.2228(6) Å. In the TGT and TGT' conformations, the spacers of the two L1 ligands show the same conformation, but the arrangements of their triazole groups are slightly different (Scheme S1 of the ). The dihedral angles between two triazole groups from one L1 ligand in the TGT and TGT' conformations are 49.53 and 72.85°, respectively. In compounds 4-7, the L2 ligands show GTT, TTT, and TTT' conformations with M(II)⋅⋅⋅M(II) separations from 15.4982(6) to 23.1215(2) Å. In the TTT and TTT' conformations, the spacers of two L2 ligands arrange in the same pattern. However, the two triazole groups of the L2 ligand in the two compounds show different directions (Scheme S1 of the ). The dihedral angles between two triazole groups from one L2 ligand in the TTT and TTT' conformations are 27.06 and 0° (or 5.63°), respectively. In compounds 8-11, the L3 ligands exhibit TTT, TGT, and GTG conformations with M(II)⋅⋅⋅M(II) distances across them from 20.6576(9) to 27.2784(4) Å. The average M(II)⋅⋅⋅M(II) distances separated by relative L1-L3 ligands gradually increase with the changes of triazole group positions of bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands.

elements.content: Moreover, the structures of compounds [Zn(L1)(m-BDC)] (2), [Zn(L2)(m-BDC)]·1.25H2O (4), and [Zn(L3)(m-BDC)]·3.5H2O (8) are related to the triazole group positions of bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands. The L1–L3 ligands possess the same flexible −(phenyl–O–(CH2)2–O–phenyl)– spacer, but their triazole groups are located in different positions of benzene rings. In 2, two L1 ligands link two Zn(II) ions with ortho-positioned triazole groups of benzene rings to form a closed loop. Neighboring loops are then joined by m-BDC anions in pairs to afford a 1D chain, which is expanded into a 2D supramolecular layered structure by π–π interactions. When the meta-substituted ligand L2 was employed, a quite different compound 4 was received. In 4, two kinds of L2 ligands bridge Zn(II) ions to yield 2-membered [Zn2(L2)2] metallocyclic rings, which are further joined by m-BDC anions into two interlocked SWMONTs. Compared with L1 and L2, two triazole groups of L3 ligand are located at the para-positions of benzene rings. Reaction of L3 ligands and m-BDC anions with Zn(II) ions gave compound 8 with a 2D 4-connected (65·8) network. In 8, linkage of L3 ligands Zn(II) ions furnishes infinite chains. The distances between neighboring Zn(II) ions linked by L1–L3 ligands are 6.1941(4) Å in 2, 15.4982(6) and 15.8188(6) Å in 4, and 20.8052(1) and 21.2548(1) Å in 8. Notably, in 2, 4, and 8, the m-BDC anions exhibit the same coordination modes and act as linkers. Obviously, the geometrical differences in L1–L3 ligands lead to the generation of 2, 4, and 8 with absolutely distinct architectures.

elements.content: The polycarboxylate anions behave as fundamental connectors when constructing CPs. The different roles of polycarboxylate anions in this work can be explained by their differences in either amounts or positions of the carboxylate groups.
elements.clean_text:
Effects of Polycarboxylate Anions and Metal Ions on the Structures

The polycarboxylate anions behave as fundamental connectors when constructing CPs. The different roles of polycarboxylate anions in this work can be explained by their differences in either amounts or positions of the carboxylate groups.

elements.content: Compounds [Zn(L2)(p-BDC)]·4H2O (5) and [Zn2(L2)(BTEC)] (7) as well as [Zn2(L3)(p-BDC)2]·2H2O (9) and [Zn2(L3)2(BTEC)]·2H2O (10) take on the effect of carboxylate group amounts on compound structures. The p-BDC and BTEC anions contain 2 and 4 carboxylate groups, respectively. Compared with the p-BDC anion, the BTEC anion has two additional carboxylate groups in the 2- and 5-positions. Usually, the additional carboxylate groups can provide more coordination sites with metal centers, which further lead to distinct structure motifs. This point can be illustrated by comparison of compounds 5 and 7 with an example. In 5, each p-BDC anion bridge two Zn(II) ions to produce −Zn–p-BDC–Zn– chains, which are joined by L2 ligands into a 5-fold interpenetrating diamond framework. Nevertheless, in 7, each BTEC anion, as a hexadentate ligand, link six Zn(II) ions with four carboxylate groups to yield 2D layers, which are held together via L2 ligands to produce a 3D (4,6)-connected (43·63)(46·66·83) net. Obviously, the structures of the CPs are seriously affected by the number of carboxylate groups of anions.

elements.content: Compounds [Zn(L1)(o-BDC)]·1.5H2O (1) and [Zn(L1)(m-BDC)] (2), [Zn(L2)(m-BDC)]·1.25H2O (4) and [Zn(L2)(p-BDC)]·4H2O (5), and [Zn(L3)(m-BDC)]·3.5H2O (8) and [Zn2(L3)(p-BDC)2]·2H2O (9) show the impact of carboxylate group positions on the resultant structures. Take compounds 8 and 9 for example. In 8, the m-BDC anions bridge Zn(II) ions with their meta-positioned carboxylate groups to form −Zn–m-BDC–Zn– chains, which are extended by L3 ligands into a 2D 4-connected network with (65·8) topology. However, in 9, p-BDC anions link Zn(II) ions through their para-positioned carboxylate groups to yield a layer. Adjacent layers are then joined by L3 ligands into a 3-fold interpenetrating α-Po net. It is clear that the position discrimination of the carboxylate groups bring on the distinct framework of 8 and 9.

elements.content: Besides, the metal center is another factor influencing the compound structures. Compounds [Zn(L2)(p-BDC)]·4H2O (5) and [Cd(L2)(p-BDC)]·H2O (6) increase the strength of the above standpoint. The Cd(II) ion in 6 has a higher coordination number than Zn(II) ion in 5 owing to the possession of larger radius. In 5, each Zn(II) ion is tetra-coordinated and situates at the center of coordination sphere defined by two L2 ligands and two p-BDC anions, forming 3D 5-fold interpenetrating diamond nets. However, in 6, each Cd(II) ion is hepta-coordinated and surrounded by a couple of L2 ligands and three p-BDC anions, leading to the formation of 3D α-Po net of 6. The structure distinctions between compounds 5 and 6 indicate that the metal centers are crucial in directing complex structures.

Compounds [Zn(L2)(p-BDC)]⋅4H2O (5) and [Cd(L2)(p-BDC)]⋅H2O (6) increase the strength of the above standpoint. The Cd(II) ion in 6 has a higher coordination number than Zn(II) ion in 5 owing to the possession of larger radius. In 5, each Zn(II) ion is tetra-coordinated and situates at the center of coordination sphere defined by two L2 ligands and two p-BDC anions, forming 3D 5-fold interpenetrating diamond nets. However, in 6, each Cd(II) ion is hepta-coordinated and surrounded by a couple of L2 ligands and three p-BDC anions, leading to the formation of 3D α-Po net of 6. The structure distinctions between compounds 5 and 6 indicate that the metal centers are crucial in directing complex structures.

elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

CPs with d10 metal atoms have been investigated for their fluorescent properties and potential applications. In this work, solid-state photoluminescent behavior of L1-L3 ligands as well as compounds 1-11 are studied. The emission spectra of L1-L3 and compounds 1-11 are given in Figure . The decay curves of luminescence are illustrated in Figure S10 of the .

elements.content: The main emission peaks of o-H2BDC, m-H2BDC, p-H2BDC, H4BTEC, and L1–L3 ligands are at 353 (λex = 281 nm), 370 (λex = 313 nm), 408 (λex = 329 nm), 346 (λex = 288 nm), 316 (λex = 282 nm), 395 (λex = 288 nm), and 324 nm (λex = 287 nm), respectively. Usually, the fluorescence observed for these organic ligands are arised from π* → n or π* → π transitions in nature.
elements.clean_text: The main emission peaks of o-H2BDC, m-H2BDC, p-H2BDC, H4BTEC, and L1-L3 ligands are at 353 (λex = 281 nm), 370 (λex = 313 nm), 408 (λex = 329 nm), 346 (λex = 288 nm), 316 (λex = 282 nm), 395 (λex = 288 nm), and 324 nm (λex = 287 nm), respectively. Usually, the fluorescence observed for these organic ligands are arised from π* → n or π* → π transitions in nature.

elements.content: Compounds in this work display strong emission bands centered at 322 (λex = 285 nm) for 1, 335 (λex = 289 nm) for 2, 369 and 491 (λex = 280 nm) for 3, 365 (λex = 286 nm) for 4, 522 (λex = 310 nm) for 5, 494 (λex = 317 nm) for 6, 441 and 516 (λex = 292 nm) for 7, 419 (λex = 305 nm) for 8, 400 (λex = 290 nm) for 9, 506 (λex = 339 nm) for 10, and 484 nm (λex = 341 nm) for 11 (Table ). These emissions for compounds 1–11 are ligand-based as for the reported Zn(II)- and Cd(II)-containing CPs. For example, the fluorescent emissions for compounds 1 and 2 can be ascribed to the intraligand transitions occurrence of L1 since analogous emission peak (λem = 316 nm) was observed for the free L1 ligand. For compounds 4, 8, and 9, the emissions originate from the fluorescence of corresponding m- and p-H2BDC acids. Moreover, for compound 8, a red shift occurs in the emission spectra with the value of 11 nm compared to free m-H2BDC. This is mainly due to deprotonation of the m-H2BDC after coordinating to Zn(II) ions, which decreases the HOMO–LUMO energy gap of the m-H2BDC acids. Compounds 3, 5–7, 10, and 11 show large red-shifts with respect to both relative bis(triazole) ligand and free organic acid. These emissions can be interpreted as cooperative effects of intraligand as well as the ligand-to-ligand charge transition as reported.

The results show that there are two luminescence centers in each compound.

elements.content: The emission decay lifetimes of 1–11 are τ1 = 2.50 ns (69.97%) and τ2 = 6.90 ns (30.03%) (χ 2 = 1.061) for 1, τ1 = 3.78 ns (60.08%) and τ2 = 12.44 ns (39.92%) (χ 2 = 1.175) for 2, τ1 = 2.83 ns (61.98%) and τ2 =13.01 ns (38.02%) (χ 2 = 1.007) for 3 (λem = 369 nm), τ1 = 3.98 ns (53.45%) and τ2 = 10.87 ns (46.46%) (χ 2 = 1.003) for 4, τ1 = 2.81 ns (48.62%) and τ2 = 11.17 ns (51.38%) (χ 2 = 1.096) for 5, τ1 = 4.19 ns (31.73%) and τ2 = 13.24 ns (68.27%) (χ 2 = 1.214) for 6, τ1 = 0.57 μs (48.04%) and τ2 = 7.48 μs (51.96%) (χ 2 = 1.025) for 7 (λem = 441 nm), and τ1 = 0.82 μs (34.74%) and τ2 = 8.35 μs (65.26%) (χ 2 = 1.016) for 8, τ1 = 0.59 μs (45.91%) and τ2 = 7.63 μs (54.09%) (χ 2 = 1.048) for 9, τ1 = 2.47 μs (22.41%) and τ2 = 9.99 μs (77.99%) (χ 2 = 1.068) for 10, and τ1 = 1.75 μs (21.34%) and τ2 = 9.54 μs (78.66%) (χ 2 = 1.051) for 11 (Table ), respectively. From the results above, we can see that the luminescence lifetimes of 1–11 are much shorter than those originating from a triplet state (>10–3 s). It is clear that the emission of light between energy states is of the same spin multiplicity. Thus, the emissions of 1–11 are fluorescent in nature.

Recently, some CPs possess luminescence behavior affected by guest molecules, which can be used for sensing of small-molecule pollutants. Thus, in this work, fluorescent properties of compounds 4–7 in diverse solvent suspensions were investigated to examine the potential sensing of small solvent molecules. Typically, the suspensions were prepared by introducing 3 mg of finely ground sample of the compound into 3 mL of methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH), acetonitrile (CH3CN), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dichloromethane (CH2Cl2), tetrahydrofuran (THF), and acetone, respectively. Each suspension was treated with ultrasonication for 30 min and then aged to form stable suspensions before the measurements. As exhibited in Figure , the emission intensities of 4–7 are largely dependent on the solvent molecules, especially toward acetone, which shows a significant quenching effect. Other solvents used in this work can also influence the energy transfer process of emissions. However, the quenching effects are less significant for these solvents as compared to acetone. The quenching effects on the luminescence intensity may be attributed to the interactions of the solvents with some sites of the compound, which can influence the energy transfer process.

elements.content: Eleven Zn/Cd-containing CPs constructed by flexible 4-substituted bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands and benzene-polycarboxylate anions have been successfully prepared by hydrothermal methods. These compounds take on diversified topological motifs. The three kinds of 4-substituted bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands behave as vital factors influencing the formation of the final structures. Moreover, structural features of polycarboxylate anions as well as metal centers are crucial to tune compound structures. The luminescent sensing properties of 4–7 show that their luminescent intensities are largely dependent on the solvent molecules. Especially, acetone exhibits the most significant quenching effect on the luminescent intensities of compounds 4–7.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Eleven Zn/Cd-containing CPs constructed by flexible 4-substituted bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands and benzene-polycarboxylate anions have been successfully prepared by hydrothermal methods. These compounds take on diversified topological motifs. The three kinds of 4-substituted bis(1,2,4-triazole) ligands behave as vital factors influencing the formation of the final structures. Moreover, structural features of polycarboxylate anions as well as metal centers are crucial to tune compound structures. The luminescent sensing properties of 4-7 show that their luminescent intensities are largely dependent on the solvent molecules. Especially, acetone exhibits the most significant quenching effect on the luminescent intensities of compounds 4-7.

Microanalysis of C, H, and N, FT-IR spectra, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data, and fluorescent spectra were conducted using published methods.

Syntheses of <bold>L1</bold>–<bold>L3</bold>

A mixture of 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol (30 mmol) and NaOH (30 mmol) in EtOH (100 mL) was refluxed with stirring for 1 h, and then 1,2-dibromoethane (15 mmol) was added. After refluxing for 10 h, ethanol was removed and 100 mL water was added. Colorless crystalline solid (2.8 g) of L1 was obtained overnight. Yield: 2.8 g (54%). The preparations of L2 and L3 were similar to that of L1 except that 3-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol and 4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol were used instead of 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol, respectively. Yields: 3.5 g (67%) for L2 and 3.1 g (59%) for L3.

Hydrothermal reaction was performed by using Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.1 mmol), L1 (0.1 mmol), and potassium biphthalate (0.1 mmol) as raw materials under 140 °C for 72 h, which produced pale yellow crystals of 1. After refluxing for 10 h, ethanol was removed and 100 mL water was added. Colorless crystalline solid (2.8 g) of L1 was obtained overnight. Yield: 2.8 g (54%). The preparations of L2 and L3 were similar to that of L1 except that 3-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol and 4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol were used instead of 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenol, respectively.
